Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Collaborative Research / Fundamental Understanding of Localized Deformation under Severe Microstructural Gradients
Award.AbstractNarration:
Program Director's Recommendation
Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications (CIMJSEA)
Proposal #1330273, 1330986

This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications (CIMJSEA) located at the Ohio State University, and Lehigh University. Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 11-570. The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research.

The research described in this proposal will provide fundamental insights into the causes of reduced creep life in welds of modern superalloys that have severe crystallographic gradients (equiaxed and columnar), compositional gradients (microns to nm), and precipitate (0 to 80%) gradients. The ultimate goal is to develop the testing methodology that will feed the creation of digital "apps" that predict the creep response of welded structures. The ability to predict localized deformation in welds will accelerate the deployment of high temperature materials. Successful deployment will lead to higher energy efficiency of utilities and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

The results of this research will provide an important step to improve the understanding of the relatively poor joint properties. This will pave the way for developing solutions so that new materials can be used to their fullest capacity in future generation power plants. The research conducted along the way will also provide an opportunity to train engineers who will be prepared to address these complex problems in materials for energy applications. Potential benefits to member organizations include deployment of digital apps for welds, capable of predicting the local properties as a function of crystallographic, compositional and microstructural gradients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nickel-base superalloys are primarily known for their superlative properties at elevated temperatures. One technologically important application of these materials is in the next generation of highly-efficient power plants where they enable higher operating temperatures and more efficient operation. Both environmental and financial incentives have driven the development of new plants and their enabling materials: it is estimated that advanced ultra-supercritical (A-USC) power plants will increase operating efficiency by 25% over current values with annual savings of approximately $16.5M and 700,000 tons of CO2 per plant. Although substantial progress has been made in developing materials to meet the needs of these new facilities, it is clear in the scientific literature that even the most advanced alloys are limited by accumulation of local damage in their structure at minute length scales (the material microstructure). Welded material appears to be particularly susceptible to premature failure in spite of recent improvements via compositional adjustment. Despite a basic qualitative recognition of these problems, relatively little work has been performed to quantify local damage effects and their impact on macroscopic, component-scale properties.

In the work performed under this NSF award, local measurement techniques were developed at The Ohio State University to better understand the relationship between a material’s microstructure and the manner in which it deforms. For example, one substantial advance was made in mapping strain or deformation on the surface of samples during elevated temperature testing. This technique was used to show the deleterious impact of certain features in the microstructure; specifically, strengthening particles in the material can grow or coarsen during testing at elevated temperature and concentrate stresses to cause premature failure. Since the coarsening of such particles is also common in other Nickel-base superalloys, their influence is important to understand in a fundamental, physical manner. This was studied through the development and testing of two custom alloys with similar compositions to the leading A-USC alloy. These simplified compositions created different microstructures in which local effects could be more easily isolated and studied by the local measurement tools described above. In addition to physical testing of materials, modeling and simulation tools were employed to develop deeper insight with regard to the formation of small stress concentrations that precede failure. The results of this work unequivocally demonstrate the negative impact of coarsened particles along boundaries within the material.

In addition to producing powerful insights into material behavior, this NSF award fostered the development of relationships between The Ohio State University and other institutions focused on outstanding scientific research. Work from this project was presented at six conferences (including an award-winning poster presentation) and five I/UCRC meetings, which facilitate connections between academic institutions and industry partners. Research funded by this award also led to the development of a collaborative effort between The Ohio State University and NASA’s Glenn Research Center, which seeks to apply the fundamental knowledge and techniques developed under the funding provided by this NSF award.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2017
Modified by: Michael J Mills
